pageProps.body:
Moving Least Square

Reference: https://www.ams.org/journals/mcom/1981-37-155/S0025-5718-1981-0616367-1/S0025-5718-1981-0616367-1.pdf

Perform weighted least square at each point x∈X\bm{x} \in \bm{X}x∈X locally (Polynomial basis, over kkk neighbourhood points within a distance threshold, with weight as a function of distance).

arg min⁡θx∑i=1kθ(∥xi−x∥2)(yi−ϕ(xi)Tθx)2\argmin_{\bm{\theta}_{\bm{x}}} \sum_{i=1}^{k} \theta(\| \bm{x}_i - \bm{x} \|_2) (\bm{y}_i - \phi(\bm{x}_i)^T \bm{\theta}_{\bm{x}})^2θx​argmin​i=1∑k​θ(∥xi​−x∥2​)(yi​−ϕ(xi​)Tθx​)2

where ϕ(.)\phi(.)ϕ(.) is multivariate polynomial basis function, θ\thetaθ is weight function, θx\bm{\theta}_{\bm{x}}θx​ is parameter to be estimated at x\bm{x}x

IMPORTANT This method is different from previous method, as it needs θxi\bm{\theta}_{\bm{x}_i}θxi​​ for each xi\bm{x}_ixi​, so nnn in total.

For test data, find θ\bm{\theta}θ by interpolating neighbourhood θx\bm{\theta}_{\bm{x}}θx​ weighted by same function of distance (interpolation needs weights normalized).

Derivatives computation

For each sample xi∈X\bm{x}_i \in \bm{X}xi​∈X with kkk neighbour points Xi=[x0…xj…xk]T\bm{X}_i = \begin{bmatrix} \bm{x}_0 & \dots & \bm{x}_j & \dots & \bm{x}_k \end{bmatrix}^TXi​=[x0​​…​xj​​…​xk​​]T. Given yi=[y0…yk]T\bm{y}_i = \begin{bmatrix} y_0 & \dots & y_k \end{bmatrix}^Tyi​=[y0​​…​yk​​]T, Φi=[ϕ(x0)…ϕ(xk)]T\bm{\Phi}_i = \begin{bmatrix} \phi(\bm{x}_0) & \dots & \phi(\bm{x}_k) \end{bmatrix}^TΦi​=[ϕ(x0​)​…​ϕ(xk​)​]T; weight Wi=diag(θ(∥xi−xj∥))\bm{W}_i = diag(\theta(\|\bm{x}_i - \bm{x}_j\|))Wi​=diag(θ(∥xi​−xj​∥))

The total gradient is:

∂L∂θ=[∂L∂θ0T…∂L∂θiT…∂L∂θnT]∈Rd×n\frac{\partial L}{\bm{\partial \theta}} = \begin{bmatrix} \frac{\partial L}{\partial \bm{\theta}_0}^T & \dots & \frac{\partial L}{\partial \bm{\theta}_i}^T & \dots & \frac{\partial L}{\partial \bm{\theta}_n}^T \end{bmatrix} \in \mathbb{R}^{d \times n}∂θ∂L​=[∂θ0​∂L​T​…​∂θi​∂L​T​…​∂θn​∂L​T​]∈Rd×n

where

∂L∂θi=−(yi−Φiθi)TWiΦi\frac{\partial L}{\partial \bm{\theta}_i} = -(\bm{y}_i - \bm{\Phi}_i\bm{\theta}_i)^T\bm{W}_i\bm{\Phi}_i∂θi​∂L​=−(yi​−Φi​θi​)TWi​Φi​

Wendland function

Reference: https://www.researchgate.net/publication/240320304_Geometric_transformation_of_the_RBF_implicit_surface

Compactly-supported Radius basis function ϕk\phi_kϕk​ for smoothness parameter k=0,1,2k=0,1,2k=0,1,2

ϕ(r)0=(1−r)+2ϕ(r)1=(1−r)+4(4r+1)ϕ(r)2=(1−r)+6(35r2+18r+3)\phi(r)_0 = (1 - r)_+^2 \\ \phi(r)_1 = (1 - r)_+^4(4r + 1) \\ \phi(r)_2 = (1 - r)_+^6(35r^2 + 18r + 3)ϕ(r)0​=(1−r)+2​ϕ(r)1​=(1−r)+4​(4r+1)ϕ(r)2​=(1−r)+6​(35r2+18r+3)

where

(1−r)+={1−rr<10otherwise(1 - r)_+ = \begin{cases} 1 - r & r < 1 \\ 0 & \text{otherwise} \end{cases}(1−r)+​={1−r0​r<1otherwise​

Radial Basis function

Related: Kernel Trick

Reference https://arxiv.org/pdf/1203.5696.pdf

Function Φ:Rd→R\Phi: \mathbb{R}^d \rightarrow \mathbb{R}Φ:Rd→R is radial if Φ(x)=ϕ(∥x∥2)\Phi(\bm{x}) = \phi(\|\bm{x}\|_2)Φ(x)=ϕ(∥x∥2​) for all x∈Rd\bm{x} \in \mathbb{R}^dx∈Rd. Radial Basis Function (RBF) can be defined for a given center xi∈Rd\bm{x}_i \in \mathbb{R}^dxi​∈Rd as

Φi(x)=ϕ(∥x−xi∥2)\Phi_i(\bm{x}) = \phi(\| \bm{x} - \bm{x}_i \|_2)Φi​(x)=ϕ(∥x−xi​∥2​)

The function values depends only on the distance between input x\bm{x}x and center xi\bm{x}_ixi​S

RBFs can be categorised as:

  • Global-supported basis function: consider all distance
  • Compactly-supported basis function: ignore point pairs beyond a predefined distance
Backlinks
  • Signed Distance Function

noteIndex.title: Root
noteIndex.body:
My personal knowledge cache using [Dendron](https://www.dendron.so)

## History
It was during my first job, at the start-up company called PixelShift.AI, that I acquired most prominent skill as a software engineer-the ability to read source code. It opened up a new way of learning and my knowledge expanded rapidly ever since. Learning new things is thriving but noting them down cogently and organized is hard. I often found myself forget the context few month later, making the notes completely intelligible. Additionally, some notes need frequent update as my previous understanding could be parochial, antiquated or even erroneous.

In desperate attempt to facilitate the noting/updating experience, I came across [Dendron](https://www.dendron.so) and found it surprisingly congenial to my personal need. With it, I have gradually grown the habit of caching, linking back and extending my knowledge base.

## Disclaimer
The notes are collections of information I found along the journey. I use backquote to denote sources, but I am likely to miss some references, so apology in advance. Also, they are my personal understandings, usually added when I first encounter the topic and will be updated only when I come across it again, so some of them could be incomplete or wrong.
